title: Charlotte mother advocates for access to IVF in wake of recent controversy
text: Charlotte mother advocates for access to IVF in wake of recent controversy “I just wish people knew the more human aspect of what’s going on.” CHARLOTTE, N.C. (WBTV) - A 39-year-old Charlotte mother shared her fertility journey that included six miscarriages and five rounds of IVF in an effort to help others see the struggle behind starting a family. Emily Carruba reached out to WBTV after the Alabama Supreme Court Decision ruled frozen embryos could be considered children. That decision shut down clinics in Alabama and caused panic for hundreds of thousands of women in the middle of IVF treatments. On March 6, the Alabama legislature passed a law granting immunity to patients and providers allowing closed clinics to resume treatments. But, women like Carruba said they fear the debate could make its way to more Southern states like North Carolina where nearly 5,000 women use an Assisted Reproductive Technology such as IVF every year. “I just wish people knew the more human aspect of what’s going on,” Carruba said. “It’s almost laughable that it’s, you know, Women’s History Month. It’s just like we are having to fight for things that our grandparents fought for. And we’re having to do that again. And it scares me so much for Nellie.” Her daughter Nellie was born in 2023. However, Carruba’s fertility journey began in 2019. “I remember two weeks after taking the pregnancy tests that very clearly said ‘pregnant,’ I was like, ‘I don’t feel pregnant. So, I’m gonna take another one’ and it said ‘not pregnant,’” she recalled. The confusion led Carruba to visit her doctor who told her she had had a miscarriage. She explained, “I didn’t understand. And the next thing she said to me, which will forever be imprinted in my mind was, ‘It’s normal. Just try again.’ So that’s what we did.” While her emotions were on a roller coaster, the longing to be a mother kept her taking the next step. “My entire life. I’ve wanted to be a mom,” she said, “You’ve been building your whole life to those two pink lines. And once they’re gone, you have to somehow like restart and let them go and it’s just this completely new reality that I would never wish on anyone.” During the next two and a half years, she had four more miscarriages, three rounds of unsuccessful IVF treatments, and then was diagnosed and treated for an autoimmune disorder. “Just devastating. Like why is this happening to us?″ she lamented. She said in North Carolina she had two choices each time she had a miscarriage: Medical management or have a DNC procedure. Carruba said the DNC route leaves behind scar tissue that often requires multiple surgeries before a women’s body can carry a pregnancy in the future. And the medical management route requires a drug called Mifepristone that is not accessible at a pharmacy in North Carolina. “[My doctor] told me the only way that I could legally get a hold of the drug in the state of North Carolina was at an abortion clinic,” recounted Carruba. “The last thing the woman said to me from the abortion clinic was, ‘Look for the women with the rainbow umbrellas. They’ll protect you from the protesters.’ I hung up, I was crying and I called a specialist in Boston and immediately booked my fifth DNC.” Despite feeling defeated both mentally and physically, in 2022 she and her husband decided to give IVF one last try. “It’s two to three weeks of pumping yourself with medication to get your body to create as many eggs as possible,” she said. “We spent six months getting my body basically ready for IVF just to retrieve eggs. And that was the first time in all of our six rounds that we got our first normal embryo.” Nine months later, in June 2023, Nellie was born. “When Nellie came out, she had her hand up in a fist like this. It was like she knew she was like, ‘Mom, we did this!’” Carruba said. Her birth was a finish line and at the same time, the beginning of a life Carruba had nearly lost hope would ever begin. “I look at Nellie every day and it is just like the biggest gift all over again. And I’m sure every parent feels that way,” she said, “But I’m just always reminded of what we went through. And just what a miracle she is.” She said the emotional toll of going through the IVF process is already hard enough without the threat of delays or needing to move states. By sharing her story, she said she hopes legislators across the country will consider each facet of women’s reproductive rights and view them independently from one another. “By making one choice, it actually impacts so much more than they see. And a lot of us are being you know, like rolled into the the abortion conversation but in return IVF patients and people who are going through multiple miscarriages are actually the ones who are who are taking the repercussions of these decisions,” she said. “And I don’t think that that’s understood.” While the conversations are happening, Carruba said she hopes North Carolina legislators will take a closer look at miscarriage care. “Miscarriage care needs to be enhanced it needs to be looked at and it needs to be handled with like kid gloves because it is so painful,” she said, “And the same with IVF. We can’t keep you know adding this layer of trauma on top of what people are already going through.” Copyright 2024 WBTV. All rights reserved.

title: UN Chief Appoints New Deputy Executive Director Of UNFPA | MENAFN.COM
text:
( MENAFN - IANS) United Nations, Dec 29 (IANS) UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres announced the appointment of Andrew Paul Saberton from Britain as the new Assistant Secretary-General and Deputy Executive Director (Management) of the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA).
According to a press note from the UN Chief's office released on Thursday, Saberton succeeds Ib Petersen of Denmark, who has been acknowledged by both the Secretary-General and the Executive Director of UNFPA for his commendable service, Xinhua news agency reported.
Saberton has been serving as the Assistant Secretary-General and Deputy Executive Director (Management) ad interim since November 2023. He has also been the UNFPA comptroller and director for the Division of Management Services since September 2016.
Bringing more than 30 years of extensive experience in management, Saberton has played a pivotal role in overseeing UNFPA's global operations, according to the press note.
Before his tenure at UNFPA, he served as a senior finance officer at the UN Industrial Development Organisation from 2001 to 2009. His professional career also includes significant experience in the private sector.
--IANS

author: Aurélie Jacquand
title: Environ 80 enfants dormiraient à la rue toute l'année dans la Loire - France Bleu
text: Loire : près de 80 enfants dorment à la rue toute l'année selon l'Unicef Alors que la rentrée approche, certains enfants ne savent pas où dormir ! 2 043, c'est le nombre de mineurs qui dorment dehors en France, selon le baromètre de la Fédération des acteurs de la solidarité et Unicef France. Un chiffre sous-évalué selon les associations dans la Loire. 2043 enfants dorment à la rue aujourd'hui en France. C'est le chiffre publié cette semaine par la Fédération des acteurs de la solidarité et Unicef France. Un chiffre sous-évalué selon Jean-François Peyrard, membre du [collectif "Pour que personne ne dorme à la rue"](https://www.helloasso.com/associations/collectif-loire-pour-que-personne-ne-dorme-a-la-rue) dans la Loire. Jean-François Peyrard : "C'est un chiffre qui ne vient pas de nulle part puisque c'est une donnée qui a été acquise via les appels au 115. Le problème, c'est déjà que tout le monde n'appelle pas le 115. Par ailleurs, tous les 115 ne sont pas doter d'outils pour répertorier tout ce qu'il y a derrière ces appels, si il y a des enfants ou non. De plus, dans la Loire aujourd'hui, le monde associatif prend en charge 200 familles et une soixantaine de jeunes isolés, donc en gros, c'est 500 mineurs qui sont déjà hébergés. Enfin l'autre élément, c'est que dans notre département de la Loire, on sait qu'en moyenne depuis presque deux ans, ce sont 80 enfants qui sont concernés par cette situation d'appels au 115. Si on extrapole en pensant que la Loire représente 1% du contexte national, on est plutôt entre 5 et 10 000 enfants à la rue." "On veut les chiffres pour pouvoir agir" "Nous, ce qu'on demande au niveau des associations sur le département, c'est que ces chiffres puissent être rendus publics, non pas pour faire le buzz ponctuellement, il ne s'agit pas du tout de ça, mais il s'agit de prendre le taureau par les cornes. Un appel au 115, ce n'est pas banal, surtout quand on a des gamins et qu'on dit qu'on est dehors ! Nous souvent, les enseignants nous appellent, il y a des travailleurs sociaux qui nous appellent, il y a des hôpitaux qui nous appellent, il y a des maternités. Si c'est inacceptable, comme c'est dit, comme le gouvernement semblait s'être engagé il y a deux ans, eh bien si c'est inacceptable, prenons ces chiffres à bras le corps et on est prêt à y prendre notre part". Un nouveau rendez-vous en préfecture le 5 septembre Jean-François Peyrard, membre du collectif "Pour que personne ne dorme à la rue", a avec d'autres associations, un nouveau rendez-vous le 5 septembre à la Préfecture de la Loire : "Pas avec le Préfet, mais avec le secrétaire général de la préfecture en présence des bailleurs sociaux. Justement, nous, ce qu'on veut, c'est qu'il y ait des actions concrètes qui puissent être décidées. Et une de nos demandes, au delà des réquisitions préfectorales qui sont possibles, c'est de dire que lorsque l'on repère des solidarités autour de ces familles, il faut qu'il y ait des possibilités pour qu'on puisse avoir accès à des logements. Des logements vacants il y en a suffisamment aujourd'hui dans la Loire". title: Synchrony Dives for a Good Cause
text:
STAMFORD, Conn. , Feb. 29, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- Synchrony (NYSE: SYF ), a premier consumer financial services company, jumped into 2024 with its ninth annual "Doubles Dive" today. More than 120 dedicated employees, including Brian Doubles , President and CEO of Synchrony, dove into the chilly Long Island Sound on February 29 th , all in the name of charity.
Continue Reading
More than 120 Synchrony employees take a polar plunge for charity at Compo Beach in Westport, Connecticut.
Despite the windy 34 degrees air temperature, the team's spirits soared as they plunged for a purpose. Since 2015, Synchrony employees companywide have participated in the event through diving, donating, or taking part in an Ice Bucket Challenge. The funds raised during the Connecticut event will go to the Connecticut -based nonprofit SeriousFun Children's Network, an organization devoted to creating summer camp experiences for children with serious illnesses and medical conditions in the U.S., India , and the Philippines .
Synchrony, celebrating 10 years since IPO this year, not only raised and matched more than $113,000 to the nonprofit this year, but has collectively raised more than $1 million for charities since 2016.

author: Ilan Hulkower
title: Woman Pleads Guilty To Trafficking Human Remains Across State Lines | The Daily Caller
text:
Candace Chapman Scott, a 37-year-old Arkansas native, pleaded guilty Thursday to trafficking human remains across state lines and conspiracy to commit mail fraud, a press release by the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Arkansas reads.
Scott was formerly employed at Arkansas Central Mortuary Services, a funeral home, and was indicted April 5th for selling 20 boxes of body parts to a man she met on Facebook, the New York Post reported . (RELATED: Woman Pleads Guilty To Allegedly Selling Stolen Body Parts From Harvard)
The DOJ’s investigation revealed that from October 2021 to approximately July 15, 2022, Scott “stole human body parts and fetal remains,” sold them and then arranged the shipping process to the buyer across state lines, the press release reads .
A judge will sentence Scott at a later date, the attorney’s office says. Scott, in exchange for her guilty plea, got the state to dismiss other charges.
Transportation of stolen property can be punishable by up to 10 years imprisonment, three years of supervised release and a $250,000 fine, according to the U.S. attorney’s office. Mail fraud can earn one 20 years in jail, at least three years of supervised release and a $250,000 fine.

Six other individuals were charged as part of this human remains trading network, according to the United States Attorney’s Office for the Middle District of Pennsylvania.”I think that the facts … underlying the indictment and in the indictment are uniquely egregious and objectionable, and we believe there is going to be some significant public outcry as a result of this,” Assistant U.S. Attorney Amanda Jegley said.
